TEXT.English: [TAB]A bora ring is a cultural site important to Indigenous Australians. Bora rings are circles of foot-hardened earth surrounded by raised embankments. They were generally constructed in pairs (although some sites have three), with a bigger circle about 22 metres in diameter and a smaller one of about 14 metres. The rings are joined by a sacred walkway. The rings were used in ceremonies, particularly for initiation. They are named for the belt worn by initiated tribesmen.

[H1]Temple of Ishtar[\H1][PARAGRAPH:2]Ishtar is a goddess of fertility, love, war, and sex. In the Babylonian pantheon, she "was the divine personification of the planet Venus." Ishtar was above all associated with sexuality: her cult involved sacred prostitution. Her holy city Uruk was called the "town of the sacred courtesans"; and she herself was the "courtesan of the gods."

[TAB]A Llogor was a place where Albanians would hide munitions with which to fight their Turkish, Serbian, and Montenegrin oppressors. Especially in the early 1900s these were important when Albanians from all regions were uniting to reclaim their land from the Ottoman conquerors: one of the movies about the war for the declaration of Albania's independence is about a homemade gunpowder mill in the mountains that was used to produce the ammunition the men waged war against their enemies with.

A Moot hill is a hill or mound historically used as a meeting place. In early mediaeval Britain, such hills were used for moots, meetings of local people to settle local business. Among other things, proclamations might be read; decisions might be taken; court cases might be settled at a moot. Although some moot hills were naturally occurring features or had been created long before as burial mounds, others were purpose-built.

TEXT.English: [TAB]The name Midewiwin is derived from a Native American term for the Grand Medicine Society, a super-secret society of which today members would nominally be called by others than the Medewiwin, Shamans. Tribal groups who had such societies include the Ojibwa, Chippewa, Ottawa, and Potawatomi, the last of whom were prominent residents of the Midewiwin National Tallgrass Prairie region from the mid 1700's to the early to mid-1800's. According to the Potawatomi, Mide' or Mida (pronounced mid-day), means mystic' or mystically powerful.' The curing rituals performed by the members of the Midewiwin relied heavily on a tradition that incorporated mystical elements arising from the beliefs about the spirits that protected the "the original people".

[TAB]Didanawisgi is the Cherokee word for medicine man. A common thread woven through all Native American remedies is the idea of "wellness" a term recently picked up by some in the modern medical professions. A state of "wellness" is described as "harmony between the mind, body and spirit." The Cherokee word "tohi" - health - is the same as the word for peace. You're in good health when your body is at peace. The "medicine circle" has no beginning and no end and therefore represents a concept of "harmonious unity."

[TAB]The Western Apache hunted deer and pronghorns mostly in the ideal late fall season. After the meat was smoked into jerky around November, a migration from the farm sites along the stream banks in the mountains to winter camps in the Salt, Black, Gila river and even the Colorado River valleys. Plains Apache hunters pursued primarily buffalo and deer. Other hunted animals were badgers, bears, beavers, fowls, geese, opossums, otters, rabbits and turtles.[PARAGRAPH:1]Eating certain animals was taboo. Although different cultures had different taboos, some common examples of taboo animals included bears, peccaries, turkeys, fish, snakes, insects, owls, and coyotes.

[TAB]Tango is Argentina's musical symbol. The Milonga dance was a predecessor, slowly evolving into mordern tango. By the 1930s, tango had changed from a dance focused music to one of lyric and poetry. The golden age of tango (1930 to mid-1950s) mirrored that of Jazz and Swing in the United States, featuring large orchestral groups.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Argentine Tango consists of a variety of styles that developed in different regions and eras, and in response to the crowding of the venue and even the fashions in clothing. Even though they all developed in Argentina and Uruguay, they were also exposed to influences reimported from Europe and North America.

[TAB]Armenian khachkars are a unique part of the national heritage. Intricately decorated crosses are carved on monolithic rocks. There are over 4,000 khachkars in Armenia, and every one of them has a singular pattern. Over time they evolved into an incredibly ornate form which reached its peak in the 12-13th centuries.[PARAGRAPH:1]Khachkars are most commonly used as tombstones, but were sometimes used as memorials. The biggest khachkar cemetery in Armenia is the Noratus Cemetery, while the biggest in the world is in Jugha, in Nakhichevan.[PARAGRAPH:1]Most khachkars do not depict Christ on the cross, but a few notable exceptions exist.[PARAGRAPH:1]

[TAB]While not necessarily this is specific to Romania - it is more correct to say this was some kind of "feudal privilege" granted to "free villages" (or to the "free peasant" - razeshi or moshneni - communities). The "serf villages" (satele de iobagi in Romanian) didn't have the right to build mills, forges or to have their own forests. They had to "buy" this services/products from their "master" ( boier in Romanian ) or "supervising" monastery ( if this was the case ) - with money or, more likely, working a number of days the land of their landlords. Opposite to this - the "free villages" had the granted right ( usually from the king - voievod or domn in Romanian ) to posses a "communal mills", or forges, judge some minor delicts by elder, even to trade non-agricultural products and so on. Most of these villages was founded in border-regions and, for their status, need to send soldiers (armed by the village) in case of war.[NEWLINE]This was a successful "social arrangement" for more than 2 centuries (XIVth-XVIth) and provided enough partially-trained soldiers to defend with some good military victories against superior enemy forces (Turkish, Polish, Hungarians and so on). Unfortunately - starting with the beginning of XVIth century the two Romanians principates ruled by Romanian lords (Walachia and Moldavia) - became the stage of internal fighting between landlords in order to impose a "friendly" king. The land and revenues of "free-villages" was a good motivation for the greed of "boier-s and their abuse. In less than a century most of "free peasant" was transformed to serfs and the remaining ones was forced to accept reduction of their "feudal privileges". Despite the fact that those measure reduced the army and capacity of defense - the fear of nobleman for possible peasant uprising lead to drastically reduction of pre-existent "peasant militia". Even so, especially in western part of Walachia, there remains "traces" of old organization until the end of XIXth century (those man formed the main part of Tudor Vladimirescu's revolutionary units in 1821).

[TAB]The Venetian Arsenal (Italian: Arsenale di Venezia) is a shipyard and naval depot that played a leading role in Venetian empire-building. It was one of the most important areas of Venice, lying in the Castello sestiere.[PARAGRAPH:1]The Byzantine-style establishment may have existed as early as the eighth century, though the present structure is usually said to have been begun in 1104 during the reign of Ordelafo Faliero, although there is no evidence for such a precise date. It definitely existed by the early thirteenth century and is mentioned in Dante's Inferno. The name probably comes from Arabic Dar al Sinaa ("Dockyard") and the concept was clearly Islamic as much as Byzantine. [PARAGRAPH:1]Initially the state dockyard worked merely to maintain naval ships built privately, but in 1320 the Arsenal Nuovo was built, much larger than the original. It enabled all the state's navy and the larger merchant ships to be both constructed and maintained in one place. The Arsenal incidentally became an important centre for rope manufacture, while housing for the arsenal workers grew up outside its walls. [PARAGRAPH:1]Venice developed methods of mass-producing warships in the Arsenal, including the frame-first system to replace the Roman hull-first practice. The new system was much faster and required less wood. At the peak of its efficiency in the early sixteenth century, the Arsenal employed some 16,000 people who apparently were able to produce nearly one ship each day, and could fit out, arm, and provision a newly-built galley with standardized parts on a production-line basis not seen again until the Industrial Revolution. [PARAGRAPH:1]The staff of the Arsenal also developed new firearms at an early date, beginning with bombards in the 1370s and numerous small arms against the Genoese a few years later. Improvements in handguns led to their muzzle velocity (and therefore their ability to penetrate armor) exceeding that of the crossbow. The Venetian condottieri leader, Bartolomeo Colleoni, is usually given credit as being the first to mount the Arsenal's new lighter-weight artillery on mobile carriages for field use. [PARAGRAPH:1]The Arsenal's main gate, the Porta Magna, was built in about 1460 and was the first Classical revival structure to be built in Venice. It was perhaps built by Antonio Gambello from a design by Jacopo Bellini. Two lions taken from Greece situated beside it were added in 1687. One of the lions, known as the Piraeus Lion, is notable for having been defaced with lengthy runic inscriptions carved in the eleventh century by Scandinavian mercenary soldiers. [PARAGRAPH:1]The Arsenal Novissimo was begun in 1473. It enabled the creation of a system similar to an assembly line, in which hulls were constructed in the newer areas of the Arsenal before being fitted out in the old Arsenal. In the late sixteenth century, the Arsenal's designers experimented with larger ships as platforms for heavy naval guns. The most impressive was the galleass, already used at Lepanto, and developed from the old merchanting "great galley". It was huge, with sails as well as oars, and was virtually a floating fortress, with guns mounted on wheeled carriages along the sides in the modern fashion. It was slow and unwieldy in battle, however, and few were ever built. The galleon, also developed at the Arsenal, was an armed sailing ship, a slimmer version of the merchant "round ship". It was useful in major naval battles, but not in the small bays and off the frequent lee shores of the Dalmatian coast. [PARAGRAPH:1]Significant parts of the Arsenal were destroyed under Napoleonic rule, and later rebuilt to enable the Arsenal's present use as a naval base. It is also used as a research centre, an exhibition venue during the Venice Biennale and is home to a historic boat preservation centre.
TEXT.French: [TAB]L'Arsenal de Venise (en italien : Arsenale di Venezia) est un dépôt et un chantier naval qui joua un rôle primordial dans la construction de l'empire vénitien. Il fut l'un des quartiers les plus importants de Venise, s'étendant dans le Castello sestiere.[PARAGRAPH:1]Ce bâtiment de style byzantin peut avoir existé depuis le 8ème siècle, bien qu'on date habituellement le début de la construction de la structure actuelle à 1104 pendant le règne d'Ordelafo Faliero, bien qu'il n'y ait aucune preuves d'une date aussi précise. Il existe avec certitude depuis le début de 13ème siècle et est mentionné dans l'Enfer de Dante. Le nom provient probablement de l'arabe Dar al Sinaa ("chantier naval") et le concept est clairement arabe beaucoup plus que byzantin. [PARAGRAPH:1]Originellement, le chantier naval ne travaillait quasiment qu'à entretenir et construire les navires privés, mais en 1320 l'Arsenal Nuovo fut bâti, plus grand que le précédent. Il permit à toute la marine de l'état et aux navires marchants les plus importants d'être tous ensembles construits et entretenus dans un seul endroit. L'Arsenal devint incidemment un centre importent de la manufacture de cordes, tandis que les quartiers en dehors des murs de la ville s'agrandissaient pour accueillir les travailleurs de l'Arsenal. [PARAGRAPH:1]Venise développa des méthodes de production de masse de navires dans l'Arsenal, notamment le système de construction en premier de la charpente venant remplacer l'ancienne méthode de construction de la coque en premier inventée par les Romains. Ce nouveau système permettait de construire plus vite et demandait moins de bois. Au maximum de son efficacité au début du 16ème siècle, l'Arsenal employa jusqu'à 16 000 personnes qui étaient apparemment capable de produire presque un navire par jour et pouvaient équiper, armer et provisionner une galère nouvellement construire grâce à des méthodes standardisées dans une ligne de production qui ne sera pas égalée avant la révolution industrielle. [PARAGRAPH:1]Le personnel de l'Arsenal développa aussi de nouvelles armes à feu dès le début, commençant par des bombardes vers 1370 et de nombreuses petites armes à feu utilisées contre les Génois quelques années plus tard. Les améliorations des armes de poings augmentèrent la vélocité de balles en sortie de canon (et par là, leur capacité à pénétrer des armures) excédant celle des arbalètes. On attribue généralement le crédit au chef des condottieri vénitien, Bartolomeo Colleoni, d'avoir monté les nouvelles pièces d'artillerie légère de l'Arsenal sur des chariots mobiles pour un usage sur le champ de bataille. [PARAGRAPH:1]La principale porte de l'Arsenal, la Porta Magna, fut construite aux environs de 1460 et fut la première structure du renouveau classique à Venise. Elle fut peut-être construite par Antonio Gambello d'après des plans de Jacopo Bellini. Deux statues de lion prises en Grèce situées à coté furent ajoutées en 1687. Un des lions, connu sous le nom de Lion de Pirée, fut dégradé notablement par de longues inscriptions runiques gravées au 11ème siècle par des soldats mercenaires vikings. [PARAGRAPH:1]La construction de l'Arsenal Novissimo commença en 1473. Il permit la création d'un système proche des chaînes d'assemblage, dans lequel les coques étaient construites dans les quartiers du nouvel Arsenal avant d'être aménagées dans l'ancien arsenal. A la fin du 16ème siècle, les ingénieurs de l'Arsenal expérimentèrent de larges navires en tant que plateformes pour des canons navals lourds. La plus impressionnante fut la galéasse, utilisée à Lépante, et développée à partir des grandes galères marchandes. Elle était gigantesque, avec des voiles aussi bien que des rames, et était virtuellement une forteresse flottante, avec des canons montés sur chariots le long des flancs. Cependant, elle était lente et difficile à manier, et peu furent finalement construites. Le galion, lui aussi développé à l'Arsenal, était un navire à voiles armé, une version plus légère des gros navires marchands. Il fut largement utilisé dans les principales batailles navales, mais jamais dans les petites baies et les fréquents bancs de sables de la cote dalmatienne. [PARAGRAPH:1]Des parties signifiantes de l'Arsenal furent détruites sous le régime napoléonien, et rebâties plus tard pour permettre à l'Arsenal actuel son utilisation en tant que base navale. Il est aussi utilisé comme centre de recherche, comme lieu d'exposition pendant la biennale vénitienne et comme centre de préservation des navires historiques.

TEXT.English: [TAB]The talking drum is a West African drum whose pitch can be regulated to the extent that it is said the drum "talks" and can be used for drum communication. Talking drums are hour-glass shaped with two heads (made from either goat, lizard, or fish skin) tuned by straps that connect the heads with each other. The player puts the drum under one shoulder and beats the instrument with a specialised beater. The pitch is raised or lowered by squeezing or releasing the drum's strings with the upper arm. This can produce highly informative sounds to convey complicated messages.

[TAB]Australians are enthusiastic about sports, both as the audience and players. Australian Rules football, soccer, and rugby are the most popular spectator sports. Cricket is a favorite summer pastime. Tennis, lawn bowling, gold, and horse racings all have enthusiastic fans. With the high amount of Australians living on the coast, swimming, sailing, and other water sports are highly popular. The country has produced numerous world-class athletes, particularly in tennis, swimming, and track.
TEXT.French: [TAB]Les Australiens sont enthousiastes au sujet des sports, en tant que les assistances et joueurs. L'Australien règne le football, le football, et le rugby sont les sports spectaculaires les plus populaires. Le cricket est un passe-temps préféré d'été. Le tennis, le bowling de pelouse, l'or, et les racings tous de cheval ont les ventilateurs enthousiastes. Avec le montant élevé d'Australiens vivant sur la côte, les sports de l'eau de natation, de navigation, et autre sont fortement populaires. Le pays a produit de nombreux athlètes de monde-classe, en particulier dans le tennis, la natation, et la voie.
TEXT.German: [TAB]Australier sind über Sport, als die Publikum und die Spieler enthusiastisch. Australier ordnet Fußball, Fußball an, und Rugby ist der populärste Zuschauersport. Kricket ist ein Lieblingssommerzeitvertreib. Tennis, Rasenbowlingspiel, Gold und Pferd alle racings haben enthusiastische Ventilatoren. Mit der hohen Menge der Australier, die auf der Küste leben, ist Schwimmen-, Segeln und andereswassersport in hohem Grade populär. Das Land hat zahlreiche Weltkategorie Athleten, besonders im Tennis, in der Schwimmen und in der Schiene produziert.
TEXT.Italian: [TAB]Gli australiani sono entusiasti degli sport, sia come i pubblici che i giocatori. L'australiano regola il gioco del calcio, calcio ed il rugby è gli sport spectator più popolari. Il grillo è un pastime favorito di estate. Il tennis, il bowling del prato, l'oro e i racings tutti del cavallo hanno ventilatori entusiastici. Con la quantità elevata degli australiani che vivono sul litorale, sport dell'acqua di swimming, di navigazione ed altro sono altamente popolari. Il paese ha prodotto gli atleti numerosi del mondo-codice categoria, specialmente nel tennis, nello swimming ed in pista.
TEXT.Spanish: [TAB]Los australianos son entusiásticos sobre deportes, como las audiencias y los jugadores. El australiano gobierna el balompié, fútbol, y el rugbi es los deportes espectadores más populares. El grillo es un pasatiempo preferido del verano. El tenis, el bowling del césped, el oro, y los racings todos del caballo tienen ventiladores entusiásticos. Entre la alta cantidad de australianos que viven en la costa, los deportes del agua de la natación, de la navegación, y otro son altamente populares. El país ha producido a atletas numerosos de la mundo-clase, particularmente en tenis, la natación, y la pista.

TEXT.English: [TAB]The construction of the Ringstrasse as a reaction to the events of the 1848 Revolutions resulted in many important cultural building being constructed. One of these buildings was the Hofmuseen, or court museums. Currently, the artistic works of the Hofmuseen are located in the Leopold Museum in Vienna.

[TAB]Not much today exists to tell us of these strange Greeks from India. Well positioned on the Silk Road from Anatolia to Far East Asia. The Baktrians were a wealthy people. They were also rich in mineral deposits such as gold. Their mints were famous for their skills in making coins.[NEWLINE][TAB]Their coins were some of the most technologically advanced, sophisticated and aesthetically pleasing to all of those from the ancient world. Finally the largest gold coin ever minted that has been discovered came from a Baktrian Mint.

[TAB]Kabaddi is a combative team game, played with absolutely no equipment, in a rectangular court, either out-doors -or indoors with seven players on the ground in each side. Each -side takes alternate chances at offence and defense. The basic idea of the game is to score points by raiding into the opponents court and touching as many defense players as possible without getting caught on a single breath. During play, the players on the defensive side are called "Antis" while the player of the offense is called the "Raider". Kabaddi is perhaps the only combative sport in which attack is an individual attempt while defense is a group effort.

[TAB]The Batavians were master horsemen. Their troops furnished great numbers of horsemen to the Roman Empire and graves of Batavian soldiers have been found in Brittan and Romania with their horses.[NEWLINE][TAB]One of the many skills the Batavian horsemen were said to have had is the ability to make their horses swim across rivers with full battle armor on all the while in perfect formation. To do this their horses must have been trained from the time they were foals to adulthood.

[TAB]A Belgian legend claims that the term "French" was introduced when British or American soldiers arrived in Belgium during World War I, and consequently tasted Belgian fries. They supposedly called them "French", as it was the official language of the Belgian Army at that time.[PARAGRAPH:1]Whether or not Belgians invented them, "frites" became the national snack and a substantial part of both national dishes, making the Belgians their largest per capita consumers[citation needed] in Europe and their "symbolic" creators. The national dishes are "steak and fries with salad", and "mussels with fries".

[TAB]Remote and inaccessible, Chuao is a village in modern-day Venezuela. It is renowned for producing some of the finest cocoa beans in the world. These beans, of the criollo variety, have become increasingly rare due to disease and interbreeding with other species of cocoa. The town itself is largely given over to production of the highly-sought after bean; the central square and many public spaces are used for drying and fermenting the cocoa.

[TAB]Boulevard Circle and its key element, channel, embrace the Old Riga from three sides, enclosed by the Daugava River from the remaining side. Ensemble of parks, created after 1856, became the first stage of fortification system reconstruction commenced in the 17th century by Swedish military engineers. Extensive parks with few loosely scattered buildings and residential blocks have become a wonderful counterpoint to the Old Riga. Boulevard Circle separates the Old Riga from Art Noveau blocks in the centre.

TEXT.English: [TAB]The most popular sport in Brazil is football (soccer), and the country is renowned for the quality of its players. The Brazilian national football team has been victorious in the World Cup tournament a record five times. Soccer is a "way of life" for millions of Brazilians and exerts an immense influence in a social context of Brazil. The history of soccer in Brazil has a direct correlation with the history of the people and perhaps can be the best explanation of the Brazil soccer appreciation and style.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]In theory, various people from different continents of the world helped build a unique Brazilian culture. The Brazilian soccer style clearly signifies culture of its people who dance samba and use creativity and swing to promote various rhythms and choreographies. Soccer then takes the form of art and its player's plays the role of soccer artists. This agility is valued by the Brazilian popular culture through the dance, capoeira, and soccer.

[TAB]Brochs are Iron Age dry stone hollow-walled structures found only in Scotland. Brochs are some of the most sophisticated examples of dry stone architecture ever created. The origin of brochs is still a subject of research. Originally, archaeologists believed that brochs were built by an influx of immigrants pushed northward first by the Belgic tribes in southeast England and later by the Roman invasion of England. However, there was never doubt that brochs were a Scottish invention. The distribution of brochs is centered on northern Scotland, but some can be found on the borders and on the west coast of Scotland. [PARAGRAPH: 1] The original interpretation of brochs was that they were defensive structures, places of refuge for the community and their livestock. Another theory is that they are castles where local landowners held sway over a subject population. A more recent theory is that brochs were the stately homes of their time. However, there is lack of proof for this theory as well. The fact that brochs are found in groupings may also suggest that they had a defensive or offensive function. Some site beside cliffs and were protected by large ramparts.
TEXT.French: [TAB]Brochs âge de fer sont en pierre sèche creux à parois des structures que l'on retrouve uniquement en Ecosse. Brochs sont quelques-uns des exemples les plus sophistiqués de l'architecture en pierre sèche jamais créé. L'origine de brochs est encore un sujet de recherche. Al'origine, les archéologues estime que brochs ont été construits par un afflux d'immigrants poussés vers le nord en premier par le Belgic tribus dans le sud-Angleterre et, plus tard, par l'invasion romaine de l'Angleterre. Cependant, il n'y avait jamais eu de doute que brochs sont une invention écossaise. La répartition des brochs est centré sur le nord de l'Ecosse, mais certains peuvent être trouvés sur les frontières et sur la côte ouest de l'Ecosse. [PARAGRAPH 1] À l'origine, l'interprétation des brochs est qu'ils sont des structures défensives, des lieux de refuge pour la communauté et de leur bétail. Une autre théorie est qu'ils sont des châteaux, où les propriétaires terriens locaux a frappé la population sur un sujet. Plus récemment, la théorie est que brochs sont les demeures de leur temps. Cependant, il ya un manque de preuve pour cette théorie aussi. Le fait que l'on trouve dans brochs groupements peut également penser que ceux-ci avaient une fonction défensive ou offensive. Certains site à côté des falaises et étaient protégées par de grands remparts.
TEXT.German: [TAB]Brochs sind Eisenzeit trocken hohlen Stein-walled Strukturen, die nur in Schottland. Brochs sind einige der modernsten Beispiele für trockene Stein-Architektur jemals erstellt. Der Ursprung der brochs ist noch Gegenstand der Forschung. Ursprünglich, Archäologen glaubten, dass brochs wurden durch einen Zustrom von Immigranten nach Norden gedrängt erste von der belgischen Stämme im Südosten von England und später von der römischen Invasion Englands. Allerdings gab es nie Zweifel daran, dass brochs waren eine schottische Erfindung. Die Verteilung der brochs ist zentriert im Norden Schottlands, aber einige finden sich an den Grenzen und an der Westküste Schottlands. [PARAGRAPH: 1] Die ursprüngliche Auslegung des brochs war, dass sie waren defensive Strukturen, die Orte der Zuflucht für die Gemeinschaft und ihre Tiere. Eine andere Theorie ist, dass sie die Burgen, wo lokale Landbesitzer hielt Herrschaft über ein Thema Bevölkerung. Eine neuere Theorie ist, dass brochs waren die stattlichen Häuser ihrer Zeit. Allerdings gibt es Mangel an Beweisen für diese Theorie als gut. Die Tatsache, dass brochs finden sich in Gruppen können auch darauf hin, dass sie eine defensive oder offensive Funktion. Einige Website neben Klippen und wurden durch große Wälle.
TEXT.Italian: [TAB]Brochs sono Età del ferro cave di pietra a secco pareti strutture trovate solo in Scozia. Brochs sono alcuni dei più sofisticati esempi di architettura in pietra a secco mai creato. L'origine di brochs è ancora un argomento di ricerca. Originariamente, archeologi brochs creduto che sono state costruite da un afflusso di immigranti spinto verso nord dalla prima Belgic tribù in Inghilterra e poi a sud-est dal Romano invasione d'Inghilterra. Tuttavia, non c'è mai stato dubbio che fosse un brochs scozzese invenzione. La distribuzione di brochs è centrata sul nord della Scozia, ma alcuni possono essere trovate sui confini e sulla costa occidentale della Scozia. [PARAGRAPH: 1] L'originale interpretazione del brochs era che fossero le strutture difensive, luoghi di rifugio per la comunità e il loro bestiame. Un'altra teoria è che sono castelli terrieri locali dove terrà regnare su un argomento popolazione. Un più recente teoria è che brochs erano le dimore del loro tempo. Tuttavia, vi è la mancanza di prove per questa teoria pure. Il fatto che si trovano in brochs raggruppamenti possono anche suggerire che avevano una funzione difensiva o offensiva. Alcuni sito accanto e scogliere erano protetti da grandi bastioni.
TEXT.Spanish: [TAB]Brochs son la Edad de Hierro de piedra seca de paredes huecas estructuras que se encuentran sólo en Escocia. Brochs son algunos de los más sofisticados ejemplos de la arquitectura de piedra seca que jamás se han creado. El origen de brochs es todavía un tema de la investigación. Originalmente, los arqueólogos cree que brochs fueron construidas por la afluencia de inmigrantes hacia el norte empujado primero por el Belgic tribus en el sudeste de Inglaterra y más tarde por la invasión romana de Inglaterra. Sin embargo, nunca hubo dudas de que brochs fueron una invención de Escocia. La distribución de brochs se centra en el norte de Escocia, pero algunas se pueden encontrar en las fronteras y en la costa oeste de Escocia. [PARAGRAPH: 1] El original interpretación de brochs es que son estructuras defensivas, los lugares de refugio para la comunidad y su ganado. Otra teoría es que son los propietarios de las tierras donde castillos celebrada domina un tema de población. Una teoría más reciente es la que se brochs casas de su tiempo. Sin embargo, no hay falta de la prueba de esta teoría también. El hecho de que se encuentran en brochs agrupaciones también puede sugerir que tenían una función defensiva u ofensiva. Algunos sitio al lado de los acantilados y están protegidas por grandes murallas.

TEXT.English: [TAB]A paya or stupa is a Buddhist structure made up of five constituent parts. Each component is rich in metaphoric content. For example, "the shape of the stupa represents the Buddha, crowned and sitting in meditation posture on a lion throne. His crown is the top of the spire; his head is the square at the spire's base; his body is the vase shape; his legs are the four steps of the lower terrace; and the base is his throne." The components of the stupa are also identified with the five elements - earth, water, fire, air, and space - held to constitute the fabric of manifest existence.

[TAB]A caer is a royal residence in Wales during the first millenium AD or earlier. Caer can be loosely translated into castle, palace, or fort, but no English word captures the same characteristics as a caer. A caer was the home to both the king, his royal family, and entourage which consisted of loyal retainers, monks, scholars, chief advisors, and bards who provided entertainment. Caers were renowned for their great feasts that lasted as long as a year. In these feasts, kings and upper classes of multiple kingdoms would meet to show wealth and status in society. Caers weren't only palaces, they were defenseive fortresses. They were usually hill forts, like the Cameot hill fort at South Cadbury in Somerset, or the coastal forts like Tintagen in Cornwall and Aberdyfi in Ceredigion. Small kingdoms only contained one caer, but larger ones contained many.
TEXT.French: [TAB]Un caer est une résidence royale au pays de Galles au cours du premier millénaire après JC ou même plus tôt. Caer peut être librement traduit en château, palais, ni forteresse, mais aucun mot anglais saisit les mêmes caractéristiques comme caer. Un caer la maison était à la fois le roi, sa famille royale, et de l'entourage qui se composait de fidèles vassaux, des moines, des universitaires, des conseillers en chef, et qui lui ont fourni des bardes de divertissement. Caers étaient réputés pour leurs grandes fêtes qui a duré aussi longtemps que d'un an. Dans ces fêtes, les rois et les classes supérieures de plusieurs royaumes se réuniront pour montrer la richesse et le statut dans la société. Caers ne sont pas seulement les palais, ils étaient defenseive forteresses. Ils étaient généralement collines fortifiées, à l'instar de la Cameot colline fort à Cadbury dans le Somerset Sud, les zones côtières ou les forts comme Tintagen à Cornwall et Aberdyfi en Ceredigion. Les petits royaumes ne contenait un caer, mais beaucoup plus gros contenus.
TEXT.German: [TAB]Ein caer ist eine königliche Wohnsitz in Wales während des ersten Jahrtausends n. Chr. oder früher. Caer kann locker ins Schloss, Palast oder Festung, aber kein Wort Englisch erfasst die gleichen Eigenschaften wie ein caer. Ein caer wurde das Haus an den König, seine königliche Familie und Umgebung, bestehend aus treuen Begleiter, Mönche, Gelehrte, Chef Berater, und Sänger, die eine Unterhaltung. Caers waren bekannt für ihre große Feste, dass, so lange dauerte als ein Jahr. In diesen Feste, Könige und der oberen Klassen mehrerer Königreiche würde zu zeigen, Reichtum und Status in der Gesellschaft. Caers waren nicht nur Paläste, wurden sie defenseive Festungen. Sie waren in der Regel Hügel Festungen, wie die Cameot Hügel Kastell von South Cadbury in der Somerset, oder an der Küste Festungen wie Tintagen im Cornwall und Aberdyfi im Ceredigion. Kleine Königreiche, die nur ein caer, sondern größere enthielt viele.
TEXT.Italian: [TAB]Un caer è una residenza reale in Galles durante il primo millennio dC o precedenti. Caer può essere liberamente tradotto in castello, palazzo, o forte, ma nessuna parola inglese cattura le stesse caratteristiche di uno caer. Un caer è stata la patria di entrambi il re, la sua famiglia reale, e che consisteva di seguito retainers, leale, monaci, studiosi, capo consulenti, e bards che ha fornito intrattenimento. Caers erano famosi per le loro grandi feste che finché è durato un anno. In queste feste, re e superiore di più classi regni si riunirà per mostrare la ricchezza e lo statuto della società. Caers sono stati non solo i palazzi, erano defenseive fortezze. Essi sono stati in genere collina forti, come la Cameot collina forte a Sud Cadbury nel Somerset, o costiere forti come Tintagen in Cornovaglia e Aberdyfi nel Ceredigion. Piccoli regni contenuto solo uno caer, ma quelli di maggiori dimensioni contenute molte.
TEXT.Spanish: [TAB]A caer es una residencia real en el País de Gales durante el primer milenio dC o antes. Caer puede ser vagamente traducido al castillo, palacio o fortaleza, pero no capta la palabra Inglés mismas características como caer. A caer fue el hogar de ambos el rey, su familia real, y que consistía séquito de leales retenedores, los monjes, estudiosos, jefe de asesores y bardos que siempre entretenimiento. Caers eran famosas por sus grandes fiestas, que duró tanto como un año. En estas fiestas, los reyes y las clases altas de múltiples reinos se reunirá para mostrar la riqueza y la condición en la sociedad. Caers no sólo son palacios, que se defenseive fortalezas. Se les suele colinas fortificadas, como la Cameot colina fuerte en el Sur Cadbury en Somerset, la zona costera o fuertes como Tintagen en Cornwall y Aberdyfi en Ceredigion. Pequeños reinos sólo figura un caer, pero más grandes que figuran muchos.

TEXT.English: [TAB]Copper has played a large role in the Chilean economy since at least 1825, when British and Americans were already competingwith other foreign investors to control Chile's copper and silver market. By 1835, Chile was exporting 12,700 tons of copper a year, much of it to the United States. Copper accounted for fifty-five per cent of the country's economy by 1860. Chile became highly dependent upon its copper exports. After the War of the Pacific (1879-83), the quantity of copper that Chile mined continued to skyrocket. Although the demand for copper put Chile way ahead of other nations in the region, its increasing dependence on copper put it at the mercy of the world market.

[TAB]A chitalishte is a Bulgarian organization and edifice which accomplishes numerous functions at once, including a community center, library, and theater. It is also used as an educational institution, where people of various ages can take a foreign language, dance, music, and other courses. The chitalishta of the 19th and 20th centuries played a vital role in protecting and developing Bulgarian culture. The first chitalishta appeared in the 1850s, and later evolved into a building that would serve many purposes.
TEXT.French: [TAB]Un chitalishte est une organisation et un édifice qui accomplit de nombreuses fonctions immédiatement, y compris un centre social, bibliothèque, et un théâtre bulgares. Il est également employé en tant qu'établissement éducatif, où les gens de divers âges peuvent prendre une langue étrangère, la danse, la musique, et d'autres cours. Le chitalishta des 19èmes et 20èmes siècles a joué un rôle essentiel en protégeant et en développant la culture bulgare. Le premier chitalishta est apparu dans le 1850s, et plus tard s'est transformé en un bâtiment qui atteindrait beaucoup d'objectifs.
TEXT.German: [TAB]Ein chitalishte ist eine bulgarische Organisation und ein Gebäude, das zahlreiche Funktionen sofort, einschließlich ein Einkaufszentrum, Bibliothek vollendet, und ein Theater. Es wird auch als pädagogische Anstalt verwendet, in der Leute des verschiedenen Alters eine Fremdsprache, Tanz, Musik und andere Kurse nehmen können. Das chitalishta der 19. und 20. Jahrhunderte spielte eine lebenswichtige Rolle in dem Schützen und der bulgarischen Kultur entwickelnd. Das erste chitalishta erschien im 1850s und entwickelte später in ein Gebäude, das viele Zwecke dienen würde.
TEXT.Italian: [TAB]Un chitalishte è un'organizzazione e una struttura che compie le funzioni numerose immediatamente, compreso un ritrovo comunale, biblioteca e un teatro bulgari. Inoltre è usato come istituto scolastico, in cui la gente di varie età può prendere una lingua straniera, il ballo, la musica ed altri corsi. Il chitalishta dei diciannovesimi e ventesimi secoli ha svolto un ruolo vitale nella protezione e nello sviluppare della coltura bulgara. Il primo chitalishta è comparso nel 1850s e più successivamente si è evoluto in una costruzione che avrebbe molti scopi.
TEXT.Spanish: [TAB]Un chitalishte es una organización y un edificio que logra funciones numerosas inmediatamente, incluyendo un centro de comunidad, biblioteca, y un teatro búlgaros. También se utiliza como institución educativa, en donde la gente de varias edades puede tomar un idioma extranjero, danza, música, y otros cursos. El chitalishta de los diecinueveavo y vigésimos siglos desempeñó un papel vital en la protección y desarrollar de la cultura búlgara. El primer chitalishta apareció en el 1850s, y se desarrolló más adelante en un edificio que respondería a muchos propósitos.

TEXT.English: [TAB]Towards the end of the 9th century, southern India had developed extensive maritime and commercial activity, especially wieconomic reform package called "doi moi" (Renovation). Private ownership was encouraged in industries, commerce and agriculture. In many ways, this followed the Chinese model and achieved similar results. Vietnam achieved significant growth over the next decade-and-a-half, making it the world's second-fastest growing economy of the time.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Upon taking power, Vietnamese communists had created a command economy in the nation. Collectivization of farms, factories and economic capital was implemented, and millions of people put to work in government programs. For many decades, Vietnam's economy was plagued with inefficiency and corruption in state programs. This trend seems to be reversing as a free market begins to take hold within the country.

[TAB]In early India, mounds of earth, brick, and stone were used to house holy Buddhist relics. These structures became known as stupas. Their housing of Buddhist relics lead to the stupas as being seen as a symbol of Buddha's final liberation known as nirvana. As their use spread across Asia with Buddhism, stupas retained their basic function as relic holders. In Tibet, where they are known as chortens, the form was employed not only for sacred burial monuments, but also for metal reliquaries that are kept on Buddhist temple altars. Tibetan chortens are overcome by elaborate tiered finials, often decorated with streamers and flags. [PARAGRAPH: 1] As well as ornate reliquaries set with precious stones and grand temples, such as the Pango Chorten in Gyantse, chortens can take the form of simple wayside markers made from little more than piles of rocks on the circuit around Mount Kailas. They can be seen throughout the Tibetan countryside. They offer weary pilgrims and other travelers the spiritual reassurance that, wherever they may find themselves, the Buddha is all around.
TEXT.French: [TAB]Au début de l'Inde, des monticules de terre, la brique et la pierre sont utilisés pour abriter les reliques saintes bouddhistes. Ces structures que l'on a appelé stupas. Leur logement de reliques bouddhiques conduire à la stupas comme étant perçue comme un symbole de la libération finale de Bouddha connu sous le nirvana. Comme leur utilisation répandre dans toute l'Asie avec le bouddhisme, stupas conservé leur fonction de base comme relique titulaires. Au Tibet, où ils sont connus comme chortens, le formulaire a été utilisé non seulement pour les monuments funéraires sacrés, mais aussi pour que le métal reliquaires sont gardées sur temple bouddhiste autels. Tibétain chortens sont surmontés par paliers élaborer embouts, souvent décorée de banderoles et drapeaux. [PARAGRAPHE 1] En plus de fixer des reliquaires orné de pierres précieuses, et les grands temples, tels que le Pango Chorten à Gyantse, chortens peuvent prendre la forme de simples marqueurs de voie de faits peu plus que des amas de roches sur le circuit autour du Mont Kailas . Ils peuvent être vus à travers le paysage tibétain. Ils offrent las pèlerins et autres voyageurs spirituels rassurer que, partout où ils se trouvent, le Bouddha est partout.
TEXT.German: [TAB]In frühen Indien, Hügel der Erde, Ziegel und Steine wurden verwendet, um Haus heiligen buddhistischen Reliquien. Diese Strukturen wurde bekannt als Stupas. Ihr Gehäuse von buddhistischen Reliquien führen zu den Stupas als als ein Symbol für die endgültige Befreiung Buddha bekannt als Nirvana. Da ihre Verwendung in ganz Asien mit dem Buddhismus, Stupas behalten ihre grundlegende Funktion als Relikt Inhaber. In Tibet, wo sie sind bekannt als Chörten, die Form war nicht nur für die heiligen Begräbnisstätte Denkmal, sondern auch für die Metall-Reliquien aufbewahrt, die auf buddhistischen Tempel Altäre. Tibetischen Chörten sind durch aufwändige Tiered finials, oft verziert mit Luftschlangen und Fahnen. [ABSATZ: 1] Neben Reliquienschreine verziert mit Edelsteinen und großen Tempel, wie der Pango Chorten in Gyantse, Chörten können in Form von einfachen Strecke Marker aus nicht viel mehr als Haufen von Felsen auf der Rennstrecke um den Berg Kailas . Sie können sich in der gesamten tibetischen Landschaft. Sie bieten müden Pilger und andere Reisende die spirituelle Zusicherung, dass, wo immer sie sich finden, die Buddha ist rund um die Uhr.
TEXT.Italian: [TAB]Ai primi di India, montagne di terra, di mattoni, pietra, e sono stati utilizzati per casa santa reliquie buddiste. Queste strutture divenne noto come stupa. I loro alloggi di reliquie buddiste portare alla stupa ad essere visto come un simbolo di liberazione finale di Buddha conosciuto come il nirvana. Come il loro uso diffuso in tutta l'Asia con il buddismo, stupa conservato la loro funzione di base, come reliquia titolari. In Tibet, dove sono noti come chortens, il modulo è stato impiegato non solo per la sepoltura dei monumenti sacri, ma anche per metallo reliquiari, che sono tenuti al tempio buddista altari. Tibetano chortens sono superate da elaborare livelli finials, spesso decorata con striscioni e bandiere. [PARAGRAFO: 1] Oltre a impostare reliquiari ornato con pietre preziose, e grandi templi, come il Pango Chorten e Gyantse, chortens può assumere la forma di un semplice marcatori strada fatta da poco più di cumuli di pietra sul circuito attorno al monte Kailas . Essi possono essere visti in tutto il paesaggio tibetano. Essi offrono stanchi pellegrini e altri viaggiatori spirituale rassicurazione che, ovunque si trovino, il Buddha è tutto intorno.
TEXT.Spanish: [TAB]A principios de la India, montículos de tierra, ladrillo, piedra y fueron utilizados para albergar las reliquias sagradas budistas. Estas estructuras se conoció como stupas. Su vivienda de reliquias budistas llevar a la stupas de ser visto como un símbolo de la liberación definitiva de Buda conocida como nirvana. Como su uso extendido a través de Asia con el budismo, stupas conservado su función básica como reliquia titulares. En el Tíbet, en los que se conoce como chortens, fue la forma empleada no sólo para el entierro monumentos sagrados, pero también de metal relicarios que se mantienen en templo budista altares. Chortens tibetano se superen por elaborar en niveles terminaciones, a menudo decorada con banderas y serpentinas. [APARTADO: 1] Además de relicarios conjunto adornado con piedras preciosas, y grandes templos, como el Pango Chorten en Gyantse, chortens puede adoptar la forma de marcadores camino simple hecho de poco más de pilas de rocas en el circuito de todo el monte Kailas . Que se puede ver todo el paisaje tibetano. Ofrecen cansados peregrinos y otros viajeros de la tranquilidad espiritual de que, dondequiera que se encuentren, el Buda está por todas partes.

TEXT.English: Monastacism grew greatly during the twelfth century, and its reflection in architecture can be found in cloisters. Before the twelfth century, cloisters were rarely seen. The earliest visible cloister in Lombardy is the clositer at S. Alberto di Pizzo Como. Lombard cloisters commonly possessed features like single colonnettes, central doorways, and archivolts of an unmoulded order. These features were replaced with features native to Provence. Cloisters with coupled colonnettes had been built in Lombardy as early as 1100. These clositers show characteristics of those of Provence, Languedoc, and Spain. The Lombard cloister is perhaps best represented at S. Zeno of Verona, which was built between 1175 and 1200. The first vaulted cloisters could be found at Vezzolano. The cloisters here date from 1180 to 1189. The vault and decorations of these cloisters commonly contained French influence. This style of cloister was reproduced in the thirteenth century by the Goths at Chiaravelle.
TEXT.French: Monastacism s'est développé considérablement pendant le douzième siècle, et sa réflexion dans l'architecture peut être trouvée dans les cloîtres. Avant le douzième siècle, des cloîtres ont été rarement vus. Le cloître évident le plus tôt en Lombardie est le clositer chez S. Alberto di Pizzo Como. Lombard cloître les dispositifs généralement possédés comme des colonnettes simples, portes centrales, et les archivolts de l'unmoulded l'ordre. Ces dispositifs ont été remplacés avec des dispositifs indigènes en Provence. Des cloîtres avec des colonnettes couplés avaient été construits en Lombardie dès 1100. Ces clositers montrent des caractéristiques de ceux de la Provence, du Languedoc, et de l'Espagne. Le cloître de Lombard peut-être mieux est représenté à S. Zeno de Vérone, qui a été construit entre 1175 et 1200. Les premiers cloîtres sautés ont pu être trouvés chez Vezzolano. Les cloîtres ici datent de 1180 à 1189. La chambre forte et les décorations de ces cloîtres ont généralement contenu l'influence de Français. Ce modèle de cloître a été reproduit au treizième siècle par le Goths chez Chiaravelle.
TEXT.German: Monastacism wuchs groß während des twelfth Jahrhunderts, und seine Reflexion in der Architektur kann in den Klöstern gefunden werden. Vor dem twelfth Jahrhundert wurden Klöster selten gesehen. Das früheste sichtbare Kloster in Lombardei ist das clositer bei S. Alberto di Pizzo Como. Lombard kapselt allgemein besessene Eigenschaften wie einzelne colonnettes, zentrale Eingänge ab, und archivolts von unmoulded Auftrag. Diese Eigenschaften wurden mit den Eigenschaften ersetzt, die nach Provence gebürtig sind. Klöster mit verbundenen colonnettes waren in Lombardei schon in 1100 errichtet worden. Diese clositers zeigen Eigenschaften von denen von Provence, von Languedoc und von Spanien. Das Lombard Kloster wird möglicherweise gut an S. Zeno von Verona dargestellt, das zwischen 1175 und 1200 errichtet wurde. Die ersten vaulted Klöster konnten bei Vezzolano gefunden werden. Die Klöster hier datieren von 1180 bis 1189. Die Wölbung und die Dekorationen dieser Klöster enthielten allgemein Franzoseeinfluß. Diese Art des Klosters wurde im dreizehnten Jahrhundert durch das Goths bei Chiaravelle reproduziert.
TEXT.Italian: Monastacism si è sviluppato notevolmente durante il twelfth secolo e la relativa riflessione nell'architettura può essere trovata in cloisters. Prima del twelfth secolo, i cloisters sono stati visti raramente. Il cloister visibile più in anticipo in Lombardia è il clositer a S. Alberto di Pizzo Como. Lombard cloisters le caratteristiche comunemente possedute come i singoli colonnettes, porte centrali e i archivolts dell'unmoulded l'ordine. Queste caratteristiche sono state sostituite con le caratteristiche natali in Provenza. I Cloisters con i colonnettes coppia erano stati costruiti in Lombardia fin da 1100. Questi clositers mostrano le caratteristiche di quelli della Provenza, di Languedoc e della Spagna. Il cloister del Lombard forse è rappresentato il più bene allo S. Zeno di Verona, che è stata costruita fra 1175 e 1200. I primi cloisters vaulted hanno potuto essere trovati a Vezzolano. I cloisters qui datano da 1180 a 1189. La volta e le decorazioni di questi cloisters hanno contenuto comunemente l'influenza del francese. Questo stile del cloister è stato riprodotto nel tredicesimo secolo dal Goths a Chiaravelle.
TEXT.Spanish: Monastacism creció grandemente durante el twelfth siglo, y su reflexión en arquitectura se puede encontrar en cloisters. Antes del twelfth siglo, los cloisters fueron vistos raramente. El cloister visible más temprano de Lombardía es el clositer en S. Alberto di Pizzo Como. Lombard cloisters características comúnmente poseídas como los solos colonnettes, umbrales centrales, y los archivolts del unmoulded orden. Estas características fueron substituidas por las características nativas a Provence. Los Cloisters con colonnettes juntados habían sido construidos en Lombardía desde 1100. Estos clositers demuestran características de los de Provence, de Languedoc, y de España. El cloister de Lombard quizás se representa lo más mejor posible en S. Zeno de Verona, que fue construida entre 1175 y 1200. Los primeros cloisters saltados se podían encontrar en Vezzolano. Los cloisters aquí fechan a partir de 1180 a 1189. La cámara acorazada y las decoraciones de estos cloisters contuvieron comúnmente influencia del francés. Este estilo del cloister fue reproducido en el décimotercer siglo por el Goths en Chiaravelle.

TEXT.English: [TAB]Historical data indicates that the Jesuits brought coffee seeds to South America with them circa 1730 CE, but there are different versions of this. Tradition says that the coffee seeds were brought by a traveler from Guyana who passed through Venezuela before reaching Colombia. The oldest written testimony of the presence of coffee in Colombia is attributed to a Jesuit priest, José Gumilla. In his book The Orinoco Illustrated (1730), he registered the presence of coffee in the mission of Saint Teresa of Tabajé, near where the Meta river empties into the Orinoco. Further testimony comes from the archbishop-viceroy Caballero y Gongora (1787) who registered the presence of the crop in the north east of the country near Giron (Santander) and Muzo (Boyaca) in a report that he provided to the Spanish authorities. The first coffee crops were planted in the eastern part of the country. In 1835 the first commercial production was registered with 2,560 green coffee bags that were exported from the port of Cucuta, near the border with Venezuela. A priest named Francisco Romero is attributed to have been very influential in the propagation of the crop in the northeast region of the country. After hearing the confession of the parishioners of the town of Salazar de la Palmas, he required as penance the cultivation of coffee. Coffee became established in the departments of Santander and North Santander, Cundinamarca, Antioquia, and the historic region of Caldas. Despite these early developments, the consolidation of coffee as a Colombian export did not come about until the second half of the 19th century. The great expansion that the world economy underwent at that time allowed Colombian landowners to find attractive opportunities in international markets. Little by little, the United States became the most important consumer of coffee in the world, while Germany and France became the most important markets in Europe. The then large Colombian landowners had already tried to exploit the new opportunities that the expansion of the international markets offered. Between 1850 and 1857 the country experienced a significant increase in tobacco and quinine exports, and thereafter leather and live cattle. These early efforts in the export of agricultural commodities turned out too fragile; they in fact were only reactionary attempts to find the greatest profitability from the high international prices of the time, rather than attempts to create a solid and diversified export platform. The production of these sectors went into period of decline when the respective bonanza of their international prices terminated, hence a true industrial consolidation was prevented.With the fall of international prices, that registered the transition from the 19th to the 20th century, the profitability of the large estates plummeted. As if this was not enough the Thousand Days War, which took place during the first years of the new century, also negatively influenced the important landowners, making it impossible for them to maintain their plantations in good conditions; this circumstance summed to the fact that these producers had incurred in large amounts of foreign debt in order to further develop their plantations, which finally ruined them. The coffee estates of Santander and North Santander entered into crisis and the estates of Cundinamarca and Antioquia stalled. The crisis that affected the large estates brought with it one of the most significant changes of the Colombian coffee industry. Since 1875 the number of small coffee producers had begun to grow in Santander as well as in some regions of Antioquia and in the region referred to as Viejo or Old Caldas. In the first decades of the 20th century a new model to develop coffee exports based on the rural economy had already been consolidated, supported by internal migration and the colonization of new territories in the center and western regions of the country, principally in the departments of Antioquia, Caldas, Valle, and in the northern part of Tolima. Both the expansion of this new coffee model and the crisis that affected the large estates allowed the western regions of Colombia to take the lead in the development of the coffee industry in the country. This transformation was very favorable for the owners of the small coffee estates that were entering the coffee market. The cultivation of coffee was a very attractive option for local farmers, as it offered the possibility of making permanent and intensive use of the land. Under this productive model of the traditional agriculture, based on the slash and burn method, the land remained unproductive for long periods of time. In contrast, coffee offered the possibility of having an intense agriculture, without major technical requirements and without sacrificing the cultivation of subsistence crops, thus generating the conditions for the expansion of a new coffee culture, dominated by small farms. Although this new breed of coffee farmers demonstrated a significant capacity to grow at the margin of current international prices, Colombia did not have a relatively important dynamism in the global market of this product. As can be observed in the following graph, during the period between 1905 and 1935 the coffee industry in Colombia grew dynamically thanks to the vision and long term politics derived from the creation of the National Federation of Coffee Growers of Colombia in 1927. The union of local farmers and small producers around the Federation has permitted them to confront logistical and commercial difficulties that would not have been possible individually. With time and through the research made at Cenicafé, founded in 1938, and the Federation's agricultural Extension Service, improved cultivation systems. More efficient spatial patterns were developed that permitted the differentiation of the product and supported its quality. Currently the Land of Coffee in Colombia includes all of the mountain ranges and other mountainous regions of the country, and generates income for over 500,000 coffee farming families.

[TAB]An Nkisi (plural Minkisi, also Nkishi/Minkishi), literally translates as "sacred medicine". The term Nkisi is the general name for a variety of objects used throughout the Congo Basin in Central Africa thought to contain spiritual powers or spirits (called "mpungo"). Minkisi serve many purposes. Some are used in divination practices. Many are used for healing, while others provide success in hunting, trade, or sex. Important minkisi are often credited with powers in multiple domains. Most famously, minkisi may also take the form of anthropomorphic or zoomorphic wooden carvings, and it is these that have principally interested art historians.

[TAB]Talented prostitutes might escape the brothel to convert themselves into courtesans, women who controlled sexual commerce and found their clientele among rich and cultivated men. Venice, where ruling families preserved their wealth by restricting marriage to one or two sons, were renowned for their many "honorable courtesans" (cortegiane oneste). Numerous courtesans succeeded in entering literary and humanist circles, and a few became celebrated poets.

[TAB]The use of fortification and guard towers have been critical throughout Croatia's military history. There geography, bound by sea and mountains, has required a defense facilitated by the types of advantages provided by guard towers.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]The defensive towers of west and south European fortifications in the Middle Ages were often very regularly and uniformly constructed, whereas Central European city walls tend to show a variety of different styles. In these cases, the gate and wall towers often reach up to considerable heights, and gates equipped with two towers on either side are much rarer. Apart from the purely military, defensive purpose, towers also played an important representative and artistic role in the conception of a fortified complex. In many senses, the architecture of the city thus competed with that of the castle of the noble men and city walls were often a manifestation of the pride of a particular city.

[TAB]The first attempts at radio broadcasting in Czechoslovakia began after the First World War. The first radio programme, made up of words and music, was broadcast on the first anniversary of the establishment of independent Czechoslovakia on October 28th, 1918, from the telegraph station at Prague's Petrin lookout tower. Regular radio broadcasts began on May 18th 1923, from a military tent in Prague-Kbely, making Czechoslovakia the second European country after the UK to have regular radio broadcasting. The year 1926 saw the introduction of several novelties, such as the time signal and regular news bulletins that were produced by Czechoslovak Press Agency.

[TAB]For centuries, most of Denmark was divided into a relatively small number of large estates, the farms of gentlemen. The seats of such estates were the herregaarde, or manor houses. There are still more than 400 manor houses in Denmark, dating from as far back as 1200 and as recently as 1915. Today, about 80 of these stately houses are open, at least in part, to the public. Time has wrought changes, sometimes peculiar changes, in these sturdy ghosts. But all are windows on a time when luxury, beauty, art and even the splendor of nature were the birthright of the lucky few.[PARAGRAPH:1]

[TAB]The hogan is considered sacred to those who practice the Navajo religion. The religious song "The Blessingway" describes the first hogan as being built by Coyote with help from beavers to be a house for First Man, First Woman, and Talking God. The Beaver People gave Coyote logs and instructions on how to build the first hogan, now known as a "forked stick" or "male" hogan. This hogan resembles a pyramid with five triangular faces. Earth may fill the spaces between the framework logs, hiding the five faceted shape and creating thick, winter-protective walls. Today, while some older hogans are still used as dwellings and others are maintained for ceremonial purposes, new hogans are rarely intended as family dwellings.

[TAB]The Fanum Voltumnae, or shrine of Voltumna, was the chief sanctuary of the Etruscans (fanum means sacred place, a much broader notion than a single temple). Numerous sources refer to a league of the "Twelve Peoples" (lucumonies) of Etruria, formed for religious purposes but evidently having some political functions. The league of 12 city states met annually at the Fanum, located in a place chosen as omphalos (sacred navel), the geographical and spiritual centre of the whole Etruscan nation. Each spring the political and religious leaders from the cities would meet to discuss military campaigns, civic affairs and pray to their common gods. Chief amongst these was Voltumna (or Veltha), god of the underworld. Historians have been looking for the Fanum from at least the 15th century but, until now, the precise location of the shrine is still unknown, though it may have been in an area near modern Orvieto (believed by many to be the ancient Volsinii).[PARAGRAPH:1]Roman historian Titus Livius mentioned the Fanum Voltumnae five times in his works and indicated Volsinii as the place where the shrine was located. He describes the meetings that took place at the Fanum between Etruscan leaders. He refers in particular to a meeting in which two groups applied to assist the city of Veio in a war it was waging. The council's answer was no, because Veio had declared war without first notifying it. Livius also says that Roman merchants who travelled to a huge fair attached to the meeting acted as spies, reporting back on Etruscan affairs to authorities in the city state of Rome. He was alone in mentioning god Voltumna, whereas Marcus Terentius Varro indicated a god prince of Etruria. That the Fanum was somewhere in Central Italy in the area between Orvieto and Viterbo is probable enough, but as Titus Livius has given no clue to its locality, and as no inscriptions have thrown light on the subject, it can be but pure conjecture to assign to it this or that particular site.[PARAGRAPH:1]

[TAB]Historical evidence and records indicate that the Finns built the first wooden saunas over 2000 years ago. The early Finnish sauna was dug into a hill or embankment. As tools and techniques advanced, they were later built above ground using wooden logs. Rocks were heated in a stone fireplace with a wood fire. The smoke from the fire filled the room as the air warmed.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Once the temperature reached desired levels, the smoke was allowed to clear and the bathers entered. The wood smoke aroma still lingered and was part of the cleansing ritual. This type of traditional smoke sauna was called a savusauna, which means smoke sauna in Finnish. The smell of smoke and wood is relaxing to most people, especially those who have never been to sauna before. As the home of the sauna, Finnish sauna culture is well established, and plays an ongoing role in the central social structure.

[TAB]Folwarks are giant Polish farms that were operated in the Polish-Lithuanian Commonwealth from the 14th century into the 20th. They were used to produce a surplus of food. The first folwarks were created on church and monastery owned grounds, but were later adopted by nobility and rich peasants. The creation of folwarks was boosted by a growing demand for grain and its high profit. Folwark-based grain export was an important part of the economy of the Polish-Lithuanian commonwealth. [PARAGRAPH: 1] The fall of agriculture goods prices in the end of the 17th century marked the start of a crisis for the folwark related economy. The noble's attempt to increase use of folwarks only hurt the economic crisis more. Until the 18th century, folwarks remained the basis for Polish noble's economic and political power. After the abolition of serfdom in Poland, folwarks used paid labor. Folwarks were abolished by the People's Republic of Poland with the PKWN decree of 6 September 1944 about agricultural reform
TEXT.French: [TAB]Folwarks sont géant polonais exploitations qui ont été opérés dans le polonais-lituanien du 14e siècle dans le 20ème. Ils ont servi à produire un excédent de nourriture. La première folwarks ont été créés sur l'église et le monastère appartenant motifs, mais ont par la suite été adopté par la noblesse et les paysans riches. La création de folwarks a été stimulée par une demande croissante de céréales et de sa forte rentabilité. Folwark fondée sur l'exportation de céréales a été une partie importante de l'économie de la polonais-lituanien Commonwealth. [PARAGRAPH: 1] La chute du prix des produits agricoles à la fin du 17e siècle ont marqué le début d'une crise pour la folwark liés économie. La noble tentative d'accroître l'utilisation des folwarks seulement blessé plus de la crise économique. Jusqu'au 18e siècle, folwarks demeure la base d'nobles polonais du pouvoir économique et politique. Après l'abolition du servage en Pologne, folwarks utilisé travail rémunéré. Folwarks ont été abolis par la République populaire de Pologne avec le PKWN décret du 6 septembre 1944 sur la réforme agricole.
TEXT.German: [TAB]Folwarks sind riesigen polnischen Bauernhöfen betrieben, die in der polnisch-litauischen Commonwealth aus dem 14. Jahrhundert in das 20. Jahrhundert. Sie wurden für die Herstellung von einem Überschuss von Lebensmitteln. Die erste folwarks wurden auf Kirche und Kloster im Besitz Gründen, sondern wurden später vom Adel und reichen Bauern. Die Schaffung von folwarks wurde durch eine wachsende Nachfrage nach Getreide und seiner hohen Gewinn. Folwark - auf der Grundlage Getreide exportieren war ein wichtiger Teil der Wirtschaft in der polnisch-litauischen Commonwealth. [PARAGRAPH: 1] Der Rückgang der Landwirtschaft Waren, die Preise in der Ende des 17. Jahrhunderts markiert den Beginn einer Krise für die folwark ähnliche Wirtschaft. Die edle Versuch zur Erhöhung der Nutzung von folwarks nur schaden, die wirtschaftliche Krise. Bis zum 18. Jahrhundert, folwarks blieb die Grundlage für die polnische edlen die wirtschaftliche und politische Macht. Nach der Abschaffung der Leibeigenschaft in Polen, folwarks verwendet Lohnarbeit. Folwarks abgeschafft wurden von der Volksrepublik Polen mit dem PKWN Dekret vom 6. September 1944 über die Agrarreform.
TEXT.Italian: [TAB]Folwarks sono gigante polacco aziende agricole che sono stati operati nel Polacco-Lituano dal 14 ° secolo in 20a. Essi sono stati utilizzati per la produzione di un surplus di cibo. Il primo folwarks sono stati creati sulla chiesa e del convento di proprietà motivi, ma sono stati in seguito adottati dalla nobiltà e ricchi contadini. La creazione di folwarks è stata incentivata da una crescente domanda di cereali e il suo alto profitto. Folwark a base di grano di esportazione è stato una parte importante dell 'economia di Stato polacco - lituano. [PARAGRAPH: 1] La caduta dei prezzi in agricoltura merci alla fine del 17 ° secolo ha segnato l'inizio di una crisi per il folwark connessi economia. Il nobile del tentativo di aumentare l'uso di folwarks solo male la crisi economica più. Fino al 18 ° secolo, folwarks rimasti la base per la nobile polacco potere economico e politico. Dopo l'abolizione della serfdom in Polonia, folwarks utilizzati pagato lavoro. Folwarks sono state abolite dalla Repubblica popolare di Polonia con il PKWN decreto del 6 settembre 1944 sulla riforma agricola.
TEXT.Spanish: [TAB]Folwarks son gigantes granjas polacas que fueron operados en la Comunidad de Polonia - Lituania desde el siglo 14 en la 20. Estos recursos se utilizaron para producir un excedente de alimentos. La primera folwarks se crearon en la iglesia y el monasterio de propiedad de motivos, pero luego fueron aprobadas por la nobleza y los campesinos ricos. La creación de folwarks fue impulsada por una creciente demanda de cereales y su alto beneficio. Folwark basado en la exportación de cereales es una parte importante de la economía de la polaca y lituana ELA. [PARAGRAPH: 1] La caída de los precios de los bienes en la agricultura a finales del siglo 17 marcó el inicio de una crisis para la folwark relacionados con la economía. El noble intento de aumentar la utilización de folwarks sólo perjudican la crisis económica más. Hasta el siglo 18, folwarks sigue siendo la base de nobles polacos del poder económico y político. Después de la abolición de la servidumbre de la gleba en Polonia, folwarks utilizados trabajo remunerado. Folwarks fueron abolidas por la República Popular de Polonia con la PKWN decreto de 6 de septiembre de 1944 sobre la reforma agrícola.

TEXT.English: [TAB]Since Roman times, bathers have traveled to Budapest to seek out its natural baths. Today, these hot springs still exist, but other manmade baths have been created. The hot springs in Hungary contain radium and other minerals that contain unique healing properties. During the Ottoman occupation of Hungary, numerous baths were built such as Rudas, Gellert, and Kiraly. Other bath houses can be found in Hungary, such as Csaszar, Lukacs, Rac, Szechenyi, and Dagaly.
TEXT.French: [TAB]Depuis l'époque romaine, les baigneurs se sont rendus à Budapest pour rechercher ses baignoires naturelles. Aujourd'hui, ces sources thermales existent encore, mais d'autres bains de l'homme ont été crés. Les sources thermales en Hongrie contiennent du radium et d'autres minéraux qui comprennent des propriétés curatives. Au cours de l'occupation ottomane de la Hongrie, de nombreux bains ont été construites telles que Rudas, Gellert, et Kiraly. Autres bain maisons peut être trouvée en Hongrie, comme Csaszar, Lukacs, Rac, Szechenyi, et Dagaly.
TEXT.German: [TAB]Seit römischen Zeiten, die Badegäste haben reiste nach Budapest, um ihre natürlichen Bädern. Heute werden diese heißen Quellen noch vorhanden ist, aber auch andere Bäder Menschenhand geschaffen wurden. Die heißen Quellen in Ungarn enthalten Radium und anderen Mineralien, die einzigartige heilende Eigenschaften. Während der osmanischen Besetzung von Ungarn, zahlreiche Bäder gebaut wie Rudas, Gellert, und Kiraly. Andere Bad Häuser befinden sich in Ungarn, wie Csaszar, Lukacs, Rac, Szechenyi, und Dagaly.
TEXT.Italian: [TAB]Fin dai tempi dei romani, i bagnanti sono recato a Budapest per cercare la sua naturale bagni. Oggi, queste sorgenti calde ancora esistono, ma altri manmade bagni sono stati creati. Le sorgenti calde in Ungheria contenere radio e di altri minerali che contengono unica proprietà curative. Durante l'occupazione ottomana di Ungheria, numerosi bagni sono stati costruiti come Rudas, Gellert, e Kiraly. Altri bagno case si possono trovare in Ungheria, come Csaszar, Lukacs, Rac, Szechenyi, e Dagaly.
TEXT.Spanish: [TAB]Desde la época de los romanos, los bañistas han viajado a Budapest para buscar sus baños naturales. Hoy en día, estas termas todavía existen, pero otras artificiales baños se han creado. Las fuentes termales contienen Hungría en el radio y otros minerales que contienen propiedades curativas únicas. Durante la ocupación otomana de Hungría, numerosos baños fueron construidos como Rudas, Gellert, y Kiraly. Otras casas de baño se encuentran en Hungría, como Csaszar, Lukacs, Rac, Szechenyi, y Dagaly.

TEXT.English: [TAB] Georgia is well known for its rich folklore, unique traditional music, theatre, cinema, and art. Georgians are renowned for their love of music, dance, theatre and cinema. In the 20th century there have been notable Georgian painters, ballet choreographers and poets. Georgian theatre has a long history; its oldest national form was the "Sakhioba" (extant from the 3rd century BC to the 17th century AD). The Georgian National Theatre was founded in 1791 in Tbilisi, by the writer, dramatist and diplomat Giorgi Avalishvili (1769-1850). Its leading actors were Dimitri Aleksi-Meskhishvili, David Machabeli, David Bagrationi, Dimitri Cholokashvili and others.
TEXT.French: [TAB] Georgia is well known for its rich folklore, unique traditional music, theatre, cinema, and art. Georgians are renowned for their love of music, dance, theatre and cinema. In the 20th century there have been notable Georgian painters such as Niko Pirosmani, Lado Gudiashvili, Elene Akhvlediani; ballet choreographers such as George Balanchine, Vakhtang Chabukiani, and Nino Ananiashvili; poets such as Galaktion Tabidze, Lado Asatiani, and Mukhran Machavariani; and theatre and film directors such as Robert Sturua, Tengiz Abuladze, Giorgi Danelia and Otar Ioseliani.
TEXT.German: [TAB] Georgia is well known for its rich folklore, unique traditional music, theatre, cinema, and art. Georgians are renowned for their love of music, dance, theatre and cinema. In the 20th century there have been notable Georgian painters such as Niko Pirosmani, Lado Gudiashvili, Elene Akhvlediani; ballet choreographers such as George Balanchine, Vakhtang Chabukiani, and Nino Ananiashvili; poets such as Galaktion Tabidze, Lado Asatiani, and Mukhran Machavariani; and theatre and film directors such as Robert Sturua, Tengiz Abuladze, Giorgi Danelia and Otar Ioseliani.
TEXT.Italian: [TAB] Georgia is well known for its rich folklore, unique traditional music, theatre, cinema, and art. Georgians are renowned for their love of music, dance, theatre and cinema. In the 20th century there have been notable Georgian painters such as Niko Pirosmani, Lado Gudiashvili, Elene Akhvlediani; ballet choreographers such as George Balanchine, Vakhtang Chabukiani, and Nino Ananiashvili; poets such as Galaktion Tabidze, Lado Asatiani, and Mukhran Machavariani; and theatre and film directors such as Robert Sturua, Tengiz Abuladze, Giorgi Danelia and Otar Ioseliani.
TEXT.Spanish: [TAB] Georgia is well known for its rich folklore, unique traditional music, theatre, cinema, and art. Georgians are renowned for their love of music, dance, theatre and cinema. In the 20th century there have been notable Georgian painters such as Niko Pirosmani, Lado Gudiashvili, Elene Akhvlediani; ballet choreographers such as George Balanchine, Vakhtang Chabukiani, and Nino Ananiashvili; poets such as Galaktion Tabidze, Lado Asatiani, and Mukhran Machavariani; and theatre and film directors such as Robert Sturua, Tengiz Abuladze, Giorgi Danelia and Otar Ioseliani.

TEXT.English: [TAB]The more enterprising tribes amongst the Getai used the rivers strewn throughout their lands to establish great networks of trade. They were able to link the variety of settlements that were found on the rivers with one another. Since the Getai had no remarkable tradition of maritime trade, the rivers were a welcome alternative. Rivers were easier to navigate than the open seas, and were found closer to the familiar settings of the mountains and forests. Trade along the rivers provided an extra source of income, and as a result, both great and small cities alike were able achieve wealth by utilizing the circuitous paths of river merchants.

[TAB]After Alaric laid siege to Rome for a third time, the city was taken and Alaric's dream came true. In a grand procession he rode at the head of his army through the streets of the great capital.[PARAGRAPH:1]Then began the work of destruction. The Goths ran in crowds through the city, wrecked private houses and public buildings and seized everything of value they could find. Alaric gave orders that no injury should be done to the Christian churches, but other splendid buildings of the great city were stripped of the beautiful and costly articles that they contained, and all the gold and silver was carried away from the public treasury.[PARAGRAPH:1]In the midst of the pillage Alaric dressed himself in splendid robes and sat upon the throne of the emperor, with a golden crown upon his head.[PARAGRAPH:1]While Alaric was sitting on the throne thousands of Romans were compelled to kneel down on the ground before him and shout out his name as conqueror and emperor. Then the theaters and circuses were opened, and Roman athletes and gladiators had to give performances for the amusement of the conquerors. After six days of pillage and pleasure Alaric and his army marched through the gates, carrying with them the riches of Rome.[PARAGRAPH:1]

[TAB]The Toltecs built many temples for many purposes throughout their empire. There is some dispute about the purposes of the temples in the early part of the empire or pre-military rule. But according to all sources they were religious in nature. In one legend about the feathered serpent god Quetzalcoatl, the temples were sources of sacrifices of not humans, but fruit and snakes to the plumed serpent god, until a military coup that exiled the high priest Acatyl Topiltzin and forced him and the other followers of the Plumed Serpent from the city. But most historians believe that the temples were, like most meso-american civilizations, places of human sacrifice, but also symbols of the Toltec majesty as they spread their influence far and wide throughout their empire and surrouding lands.

[TAB]A hambar is a corn crib or small structure used for storing and drying corn in the Balkans and bordering regions in the Pannonian plain. Although many hambars are generally obsolete, there are still some hambars found throughout the Balkan region. The word originates from the Turkish word ambar meaning "storehouse, warehouse, or repository." The word in its original form, ambar, is also used in Serbia.
TEXT.French: [TAB]Un hambar est une huche de maïs ou une petite structure utilisée pour stocker et sécher le maïs aux Balkans et des régions encadrantes dans la plaine de Pannonian. Bien que beaucoup de hambars soient généralement désuets, il restent quelques hambars trouvés dans toute la région balkanique. Le mot provient de la signification ambar de mot turc « entrepôt, entrepôt, ou dépôt. » Le mot sous sa forme originale, ambar, est également employé en Serbie.
TEXT.German: [TAB]Ein hambar ist eine Maiskrippe oder eine kleine Struktur, die für die Speicherung und das Trocknen von Mais in den Balkan und die einfassenden Regionen in der Pannonian Ebene benutzt werden. Obgleich viele hambars im Allgemeinen überholt sind, gibt es noch etwas hambars, die während der Balkan Region gefunden werden. Das Wort entsteht von der ambar Bedeutung des türkischen Wortes Lagerhaus, Lager oder Behälter. Das Wort in seiner ursprünglichen Form, ambar, wird auch in Serbien verwendet.
